DOC.HEAD: 2,000 In Noisy March For Political Reform
LaserPhoto TPE2
DOC.TEXT: About 2,000 opposition supporters marched downtown today in a noisy but peaceful demonstration on Constitution Day to demand swifter political reform. About 2,000 riot policemen backed by water cannon trucks guarded the National Assembly building from behind barbed-wire barricades. Earlier, 11 legislators from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party scuffled with guards at the National Assembly who tried to prevent them from carrying protest banners into the building. Three assemblymen said they suffered bruises in the brief scuffle before they were allowed to take the banners into the National Assembly where President Lee Teng-hui appealed for greater tolerance toward dissent. ``In a more open society we need to have the magnanimity to tolerate dissent,'' Lee told the assembly. ``As our society faces a transition, we need to build a new political culture and strengthen psychological reconstruction.'' As Lee and Premier Lee Huan addressed the assembly, Taiwan's electoral college, the opposition assemblymen unfurled their banners which demanded ``Aging Assemblymen Step Down,'' ``We Want Universal Suffrage For The Presidency'' and ``Please Proclaim Taiwan an Independent State.'' Both the Nationalist government in Taiwan and the rival Communist government in Beijing are opposed to independence for Taiwan, which they say is a Chinese province. Both say they are the sole legitimate government of all China, and Beijing has indicated it may use force to prevent Taiwan from gaining independence. The 780-member National Assembly, which meets every six years to elect the president, is dominated by aging members, many in their 70s, who were elected on the Chinese mainland before the Nationalists fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Communists. Most of the aged assemblymen are Nationalist supporters and they have been frozen in office to support the Nationalist claim to be the legitimate government of China. The opposition has demanded the retirement of the aged assemblymen. The government has offered them handsome pensions if they step down, but has refused to force them to retire. ``The old members did not face re-election for 40 years (and they) cannot represent Taiwanese people,'' said Chou Ching-yu, a Democratic Progressive Party assemblywoman. ``They don't have the right to elect our president.'' Lee, who is expected to be re-elected president in March, told opposition assemblymen at a meeting last week that political reforms must be introduced slowly to maintain Taiwan's stability.
